title: Biosafety Fundamentals Quiz
subtitle: Assess your understanding of biosafety levels, cabinet usage, and laboratory best practices.

questions.prompt: This biosafety level classification is appropriate for clinical, diagnostic, teaching, and other laboratories that deal with indigenous moderate-risk agents linked with human disease, and are present in a community.
questions.explanation: BSL-2 laboratories handle indigenous agents that pose moderate hazards and are commonly encountered in clinical and diagnostic settings.

questions.prompt: This biosafety level classification applies to facilities handling indigenous or exotic agents with a potential for respiratory transmission that may be a cause for lethal infection.
questions.explanation: BSL-3 work focuses on agents transmissible through the respiratory route that can cause serious or lethal disease, requiring specialized containment and engineering controls.

questions.prompt: At which biosafety level should cell lines that are of human or primate origin, derived from lymphoid or tumor tissue, clinical samples, or known to contain mycoplasma be handled?
questions.explanation: Human and primate-derived cell lines can harbor blood-borne pathogens or adventitious agents, so they must be handled under BSL-2 containment.

questions.prompt: What facilities are needed in a BSL-2 laboratory?

options.label: Negative pressure, double-door entry, sealed penetrations
An autoclave, an eyewash station, a biosafety cabinet for procedures creating aerosols
Positive pressure suits, a Class III BSC, and a dedicated building
Sinks and windows can be open

questions.explanation: BSL-2 laboratories require core secondary barriers such as an autoclave, eyewash station, and certified biosafety cabinets for aerosol-generating work.

questions.prompt: The following are the laboratory facility requirements of BSL-4, except which option?

options.label: Class III biosafety cabinet or positive pressure suits
Negative pressure and dedicated exhaust air
Open bench top and sink required in the lab room

questions.explanation: BSL-4 facilities are fully sealed and do not permit open bench work; sinks are specialized and not open to the room.

questions.prompt: Where should materials be placed inside a biosafety cabinet to maintain proper laminar airflow?

options.label: Crowded together in the center for efficiency
At least 2-3 inches from the grill on the front and back
On the very edge of the work surface

questions.explanation: Keeping materials a few inches from the intake and exhaust grills preserves the laminar airflow pattern that provides protection.

questions.prompt: Where should the autoclavable biohazard collection bag and pipette collection tray be placed?

options.label: Inside the biosafety cabinet for easy access
On a separate cart or bench outside the cabinet
On the floor next to the user

questions.explanation: Waste containers inside the cabinet disrupt airflow and increase contamination risk, so they must be placed just outside the BSC.

questions.prompt: Which component of a biosafety cabinet is essential for providing clean air?
questions.explanation: The HEPA filter removes 99.97% of particulates and microorganisms, ensuring sterile airflow within the cabinet.

questions.prompt: How often should the UV lamp in a biosafety cabinet be cleaned to maintain germicidal effectiveness?
questions.explanation: Dust accumulation degrades UV performance, so a weekly cleaning with 70% ethanol is standard practice.

questions.prompt: What is the ideal location for a biosafety cabinet within a laboratory?

options.label: In a high-traffic area near a doorway
In a low-traffic area away from air currents and doors
Next to an open window for ventilation

questions.explanation: Air currents from doors, windows, or HVAC vents can disrupt the protective air curtain, so BSCs belong in calm, low-traffic areas.

questions.prompt: Which type of biosafety cabinet has the most basic and now largely obsolete design, providing only personnel and environmental protection?
questions.explanation: Class I cabinets protect personnel and the environment but not the product, making them unsuitable for many modern applications.

questions.prompt: Why is the overhead clearance of a biosafety cabinet important?

options.label: To make the cabinet look balanced
To allow users to see inside easily
To ensure proper airflow into the exhaust HEPA filter
To store supplies on top of the cabinet

questions.explanation: Adequate clearance prevents back pressure and allows the exhaust HEPA filter to function properly, maintaining containment.
